[[University of South Carolina]] |children = 4 |spouse = Virginia Utsey |profession = [[Lawyer]] |religion = [[Methodist]] |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Donald Stuart Russell''' (February 22, 1906{{ndash}} February 22, 1998) was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[United States Senate|Senator]] from [[South Carolina]]. He served from 1965 to 1966. He also served as the [[List of Governors of South Carolina|107th]] [[Governor of South Carolina]], 1963-1965. Russell was a protege of former [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[James F. Byrnes]] and served as [[Assistant Secretary of State for Administration]] from 1945 to 1947. From 1952 to 1957 he served as [[president]] of the [[University of South Carolina]]. He ran for governor in [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1958|1958]] but lost the Democratic [[primary election|primary]] to [[Ernest Hollings|Ernest F."Fritz" Hollings]]. Four years later he was [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1962|elected]] [[governor]]. He resigned as governor in 1965 upon the death of Sen. [[Olin D. Johnston]] and was appointed by the new governor, [[Robert Evander McNair|Robert E. McNair]], to fill the vacancy created by Johnston's death. In the Democratic primary for the [[special election]] in 1966 to fill the remainder of Johnston's term, he again lost to Fritz Hollings. Russell was appointed U.S. District Judge for the [[United States District Court for the District of South Carolina|District of South Carolina]] by President [[Lyndon Johnson]] in 1966, to fill the vacancy created by the death of Russell's former law partner, [[Charles Cecil Wyche]]. In 1971, President Richard Nixon appointed Russell to the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit]], where he served until his death, on his 92nd birthday in 1998. ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} *[http://www.sc.edu/library/socar/mpc/russell.html Donald S.
